subject: Re: [junit] Re: Help plz...
msgSnippet: Well, I would be very interested to find out that you could significantly increase performance simply by reducing the size of the constant pool! All my
messageBody:
Well, I would be very interested to find out that you could
significantly increase performance simply by reducing the size of the
constant pool!

All my knowledge and experience of Java leads me to believe that you
will find no significant performance increase and that this is a
puerile exercise. If you can demonstrate more than a single percentage
point of difference in performance please post the results and I will
eat my proverbial hat.

If there is a relationship between size of code and performance, it is
that complex code has more interactions so feels slower than small
simple code. It's nothing to do with the size of the identifiers!

The point that lots of people are making here is plain: Well factored,
meaningfully written code is vastly superior to badly written,
sprawling cryptic code.

This is true even for performance critical code. If there are
bottlenecks revealed by your profiler, having well factored meaningful
code will allow you to do something about them. Badly maintained and
purposely obfuscated code will discourage you from even trying, in case
you break something you don't understand.



On Wed, 2003-09-24 at 02:38, Jason Rogers wrote:
> On Tue, 23 Sep 2003 19:30:13 -0000, "ssmith12345uk" <shauns@...>
> said:
> > I must confess, I am definitely one of the 'comment extremely
> > sparsely' crowd. What might be interesting is if we perhaps wrote a
> > Ruby program to process a Java source tree, replacing the symbols
> > with the smallest identifiers possible, unless they are tagged with
> > a @published tag for external compatibility reasons. I would expect
> > to be able to produce a readable and maintainable program to do this
> > with very few comments indeed. I also expect to be able to write a
> > program to convert a stack trace back to the original symbols, again
> > with very few comments.
> >
> > Do you think that might be a worthwhile or interesting exercise?
>
> I, for one, would be very interested in this.
>
> --
> =jason
> [:question | ^One]
